user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_SetLocalTime_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_SetLocalTime_Impl(const OS_time_t *time_struct)
{
    int             Status;
    int32           ReturnCode;
    struct timespec TimeSp;

    TimeSp.tv_sec  = OS_TimeGetTotalSeconds(*time_struct);
    TimeSp.tv_nsec = OS_TimeGetNanosecondsPart(*time_struct);

    Status = clock_settime(OSAL_GETTIME_SOURCE_CLOCK, &TimeSp);

    if (Status == 0)
    {
        ReturnCode = OS_SUCCESS;
    }
    else
    {
        ReturnCode = OS_ERROR;
    }

    return ReturnCode;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_SetLocalTime_Impl:
typedef int32_t   int32
...
typedef struct
{
    int64 ticks; /**< Ticks elapsed since reference point */
} OS_time_t
...
#define OSAL_GETTIME_SOURCE_CLOCK CLOCK_REALTIME
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
#define OS_ERROR (-1)
...
static inline int64 OS_TimeGetTotalSeconds(OS_time_t tm)
{
    return (tm.ticks / OS_TIME_TICKS_PER_SECOND);
}
...
static inline uint32 OS_TimeGetNanosecondsPart(OS_time_t tm)
{
    return (uint32)OS_TimeGetFractionalPart(tm) * OS_TIME_TICK_RESOLUTION_NS;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I inspected the target function and the related definitions for compiler language extensions documented as extensions by common compilers. I found none of the following compiler-specific or nonstandard language features: no use of compiler intrinsic keywords or identifiers such as __attribute__, __asm__, __inline__ (compiler-specific form), __typeof__, typeof, __extension__, or other vendor-specific keywords; no inline assembly; no nonstandard storage-class specifiers or pragmas; no use of compiler-specific builtins. The code uses standard C constructs (typedefs based on stdint types, ordinary macros, standard C99 'static inline' functions) and POSIX API types/functions (struct timespec, clock_settime, CLOCK_REALTIME) which are platform/library APIs, not compiler language extensions. Therefore there are no code fragments that need investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 (language extensions). If you want me to treat POSIX APIs as a potential issue, state that explicitly and I will flag their use.
